Since, natural neural networks work good enough :), couldn't decreasing our=
 precision and allowing multiple connections be a better way of making ANNs=
?
I dont have any idea how this might be achieved.. but I believe that the =
simpler we keep our domain and smaller our search space, the easier it woul=
d be to come up with solutions..
If we could give higher probability of cha=
nging weights than adding new connections, we would in effect be searching =
in a concentrated part of the search-space first before moving to higher le=
vels..
That brings me to another idea that I once had: Shouldn't we decreas=
e the precision of our weights? 
Since searching in let's say 15 digits aft=
er decimal would be many times more difficult than searching in 8-10 digits=
 after decimal.
And the results would not differ much.
What do the others s=
ay?
Can we achieve this somehow?

Umer..


  ----- Original Message ----- 
=
  From: John Arrowwood 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, June=
 02, 2004 9:37 AM
  Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Connections


  Natural neural =
networks are hardware-limited.  They can't represent a weight 
  more than =
some limit, by virtue of their physical structure.  Having 
  multiple conn=
ections between neurons is a work-around allowing it to have 
  more dynami=
c range available to it.

  Artificial neural networks with double-precisio=
n floating point weights have 
  more than enough precision for the tasks w=
e are assigning to them.  Having 
  multiple connections is an unnecessary =
redundancy.  Can it work?  Obviously. 
    But it is an inefficient way to =
do things, and adds nothing of value in 
  the process that I am aware of.
=


  >From: "Umer Iqbal" <umeriqbal81@...>
  >Reply-To: neat@yahoogr=

ural networks, do we have more than one 
  >connections between two neurons=
?
  >If so, should we or shouldn't we incorporate them in ANNs ?
  >
  >Ume=
r..
  >

  >   From: yurifromtomsk

 Subject: [neat] Re: Connections
  >
  >
  >   > Here's a thought...  Why g=
ive connections a unique innovation number 
  >at all?
  >   >   Why not as=
sign their unique ID based on the innovation numbers of 
  >the
  >   > nod=
es they connect?  If you create a new connection between nodes 253 
  >and
=
  >   > 275, then the ID for the connection could be "253:275".  Store the
=
  >   > connections in a hash table, and you have instant prevention of 
  =
>duplicates.
  >   > Then, even if a connection is created 10 generations l=
ater, if it 
  >connects
  >   > the same nodes, it's the same gene.  Even =
if the organism has 
  >subsequently
  >   > gone off and formed its own sp=
ecies.
  >   >
  >   > Any reason why that wouldn't work?
  >
  >   I think=
 there is a problem to appear. You idea supposes some global pool 
  >for c=
onnections information. Right? So there is no way to keep connections 
  >t=
hat do link the same neurons but have different weights. It's just because =

  >such connections are always the same for hash function as they have sim=
ilar 
  >IDs.
